content: The Act titled "Safe Nursing and Patient Care Act of 2001" is cited as the short title. The Congress finds that higher nurse staffing levels lead to better patient outcomes, but there are challenges in recruiting and retaining nursing staff. About 500,000 licensed nurses are not practicing nursing due to job dissatisfaction and overtime work. Higher nurse staffing levels lead to better patient outcomes, but challenges exist in recruiting and retaining nursing staff. Approximately 500,000 licensed nurses are not practicing due to job dissatisfaction and overtime work. Health care providers still rely on mandatory overtime as a staffing method. The widespread use of mandatory overtime in healthcare contributes to nurse dissatisfaction and compromises patient safety, as highlighted by a recent report. Limiting mandatory overtime can ensure public safety and improve healthcare facility operations. Limiting mandatory overtime in healthcare will ensure public safety, improve healthcare facility operations, and help retain and recruit nurses. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON MANDATORY OVERTIME FOR NURSES. Provider agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include compliance with limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses. Provider agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include compliance with limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses, prohibiting providers from requiring nurses to work in excess of specified limits. Limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses include prohibiting them from working in excess of scheduled shifts, 12 hours in a 24-hour period, or 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period, with exceptions allowed. The limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses include restrictions on working beyond scheduled shifts, 12 hours in a 24-hour period, or 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period, with exceptions during declared state of emergency for providing exceptional medical services to the community. During a declared state of emergency, providers of services may be exempt from restrictions on mandatory overtime for nurses if they are expected to deliver exceptional medical services to the community. During a declared state of emergency, providers of services may be exempt from restrictions on mandatory overtime for nurses if efforts to fill staffing needs have been made and the work requirement does not extend past the end of the emergency declaration. The Secretary investigates complaints of violations filed by nurses and takes action against providers found in violation. If a provider violates the provisions, the Secretary can require them to establish a plan of action to address the violation and may impose civil money penalties. Nurses are protected from discrimination, retaliation, or penalties in any aspect of employment by providers of services. A provider of services cannot penalize, discriminate, or retaliate against a nurse for refusing mandatory overtime or reporting violations. A nurse who refuses to work mandatory overtime or reports violations in good faith cannot be penalized by the provider of services. A nurse cannot be penalized for refusing mandatory overtime or reporting violations to regulatory agencies, private accreditation bodies, or management personnel. A provider of services cannot retaliate against employees who report violations to regulatory agencies, private accreditation bodies, or discuss violations with other employees. Employees cannot be retaliated against for reporting violations or suspected violations to regulatory agencies, private accreditation bodies, or discussing them with other employees. Additionally, a provider of services cannot file a complaint against a nurse with the State disciplinary agency for refusing to work mandatory overtime. Nurses are deemed to be acting in good faith when refusing such requests. A nurse cannot be retaliated against for refusing to work mandatory overtime, and they are deemed to be acting in good faith when they believe the information reported is true and a violation has occurred or may occur. Each provider of services must post a notice specifying nurses' rights, including the right to file a complaint if they reasonably believe a violation has occurred or may occur. The provider of services must post a sign specifying nurses' rights, including the right to file a complaint with the Secretary for violations. Nurses' schedules must also be regularly posted in a conspicuous manner. The provider of services must post nurse schedules in a conspicuous manner and make daily schedules available to nurses upon request. Nurses have the right to file a complaint with the Secretary for violations, and civil money penalties may be imposed. The Secretary requires providers of services to post nurse schedules and make daily schedules available to nurses upon request. Violations of this requirement may result in civil money penalties of up to $10,000 per knowing violation. The Secretary may impose civil money penalties of up to $10,000 for each knowing violation of the provisions regarding nurse schedules by providers of services. More severe penalties can be imposed for patterns of repeated violations. The Secretary can impose more severe civil money penalties for providers who establish patterns of repeated violations of nurse schedule provisions. The administration of penalties follows the same provisions as section 1128A. The Secretary can impose civil money penalties on providers for repeated violations of nurse schedule provisions, following the same provisions as section 1128A. Penalties are published on the Department of Health and Human Services website. The Department of Health and Human Services can impose civil money penalties on providers for violations, with details published on their website. Penalties for previous ownership changes will not be disclosed after a year. After a change in ownership, penalties imposed on healthcare providers will no longer be published by the Secretary on their website after a 1-year period. Mandatory overtime is defined as hours worked in excess of the specified time limits, except in certain circumstances. The term 'mandatory overtime' refers to hours worked beyond specified limits, requested by a service provider to a nurse, with potential adverse consequences for refusal. The term 'overtime' refers to time worked beyond specified periods. A 'nurse' is defined as a registered nurse or licensed practical nurse. The term 'standards of safe patient care' refers to recognized professional standards in healthcare, excluding emergencies from labor disputes or understaffing. The amendments made by this section will take effect one year after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will conduct a study on mandatory overtime in federally operated medical facilities to determine if practices are inconsistent with the Social Security Act. Medical facilities have practices and policies regarding overtime for nurses that do not align with the Social Security Act. Federally operated medical facilities include hospitals, clinics, and home health care facilities run by the Department of Veterans Affairs, Department of Defense, or other agencies. The term "federally operated medical facilities" refers to hospitals, clinics, and home health care facilities operated by the Department of Veterans Affairs, Department of Defense, or other US agencies. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must submit a report to Congress within 6 months of the enactment of the Act, including recommendations from a study conducted on these facilities.
